author: Maria Armental
title: Microsoft CEO’s compensation drops 78% on reduced stock award - MarketWatch
text:
Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +0.23% Chief Executive Satya Nadella’s total compensation in 2015 fell to $18.3 million, a 78% drop largely tied to a drop in his stock compensation.
Meanwhile, his base salary for the year ended June 30 jumped 31% to $1.2 million and his cash bonus rose 20% to $4.3 million, according to a securities filing.
Nadella’s compensation last year was boosted by a $59.2 million restricted stock grant that he is eligible to receive in 2019. That $59.2 million figure — which had boosted his total compensation to $84.3 million, making the 48-year-old one of the highest paid tech executives — assumes Microsoft’s stock-price gains and dividend payouts top those of 60% of the companies in the S&P 500 in each of three overlapping five-year stretches ending in 2019, 2020 and 2021.
Chief Financial Officer Amy E. Hood’s total compensation, meanwhile, fell 16% to $8.8 million and Chief Operating Officer B. Kevin Turner’s dropped 46% to $12.2 million. The lower compensation, like Nadella’s, was largely because of lower stock awards.
Margaret L. Johnson, who joined the company in September 2014 as executive vice president for business development, was paid $14.5 million, including a one-time hiring cash bonus of $2.5 million.
An extended version of this report appears at WSJ.com.
